historicalDescription: This narrow street was located near a convent of Teresian nuns in the sestiere of Dorsoduro. The area was known for its religious institutions and quiet residential neighborhoods in the 15th century.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the Carmelite nuns of the Order of Saint Teresa who established a convent near Calle de le Terese in the 17th century. This dock would have served the convent and surrounding community.

This dock name reflects the wool dyeing workshops that operated in this area during the Renaissance period. The textile industry was vital to Venice's economy, and many specialized craftsmen had workshops near Calle de le Terese.

Named for its proximity to the Church of Santa Maria dei Carmini and the Carmelite order. This religious connection would be particularly appropriate for a dock near Calle de le Terese, which itself references the Teresine (Discalced Carmelites).

canalPoints.historicalName: Riva di San Nicolò dei Mendicoli
canalPoints.englishName: Bank of Saint Nicholas of the Beggars
canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the nearby parish church of San Nicolò dei Mendicoli, one of Venice's oldest churches. This area was historically home to poorer Venetians, including many fishermen and laborers who would use this dock.

Refers to a prominent family or confraternity of godfathers who may have lived or operated near Calle de le Terese. Confraternities were important social institutions in Renaissance Venice, often maintaining their own docks for members' use.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the Teresine nuns (Discalced Carmelites) who established a convent in this area during the 17th century. The bridge would have been a vital connection to their religious complex.

Named for the wool carders who worked in workshops near Calle de le Terese. Venice's textile industry was significant during the Renaissance, and this area housed artisans who prepared wool for weaving.
Likely named for a devotional cross or small shrine that would have been placed near the bridge, possibly connected to the Teresine nuns' religious practices in the area.
Named after the nearby Church of San Nicolò da Tolentino and the Theatine order who managed it. This bridge would have connected the Terese area with the important religious complex of the Tolentini.
Named for craftsmen who constructed wooden pergolas and trellises for Venetian gardens and courtyards, who likely had workshops in this artisanal district near Calle de le Terese.
Named for the transport of unprocessed wool that would cross this bridge on its way to the workshops in the Terese district, reflecting Venice's important textile trade during the Renaissance.

Named for the shipbuilders who would have used this route to reach the nearby Squero (shipyard). The bridge would have connected the residential area of Terese with workshops involved in Venice's maritime industry.

connection.englishName: Bridge of the Ancient Barefoot Friars
connection.historicalDescription: Named for the barefoot Carmelite friars who had a presence in this area before the female branch (Teresine) established their convent. This bridge would have been on a path frequently used by these friars.
Named for Venice's important Water Magistracy officials who oversaw canal maintenance. This bridge might have been near one of their inspection points or administrative buildings in the Terese area.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Carmelite convent of Saint Teresa established in the 17th century in this area. The Teresians were a reformed branch of the Carmelite order and their convent was a significant religious institution in this part of Venice.
This street was originally a canal that was filled in. Named after the Carmelite order, which had a strong presence in this area with the nearby Church of the Carmini and the Terese convent.
This canalside walkway was named after the nuns who resided in the nearby Terese convent. Fondamenta traditionally refers to streets running alongside canals.
Named after the wool trade that was prevalent in this area during the Renaissance. The Terese district had numerous workshops where wool was processed and woven into textiles.

A covered passageway named after the cloth dyers who operated in this area. The textile industry required specialized artisans to dye fabrics, and they often worked near the canals for easy waste disposal and water access.
Named after rope makers who had workshops in this area. Venice's maritime economy required vast quantities of ropes for its ships, and rope making was an important craft in the Terese district.

One of the main paved streets (salizada) in the area, named after Saint Teresa of Ávila, the patron saint of the Teresian Carmelite order whose convent was nearby. Salizadas were wider and paved earlier than ordinary calli.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Small Square of the Spinning Wheel
buildingPoints.streetDescription: This small square was named after the spinning wheels used in the textile industry that flourished in the area. Spinning wool was a common occupation for women who might have worked for the textile merchants.

A commercial street (ruga) where wool workers had their shops and workshops. The wool trade was significant in Venice's economy, and this area contained many artisans involved in various stages of wool processing.
Named after the dining hall of the Terese convent. Religious institutions were central to neighborhood organization in Renaissance Venice, and their buildings often gave names to nearby streets.

This canalside walkway may have been named after a workshop that produced shields or after a family with shields in their coat of arms. Military equipment production was an important industry in Venice.

Named after the Pisani family, one of Venice's nobili families who may have had a palazzo in this area. Noble families often gave their names to the courts and streets where their residences were located.

Originally a canal that was filled in, named after charitable works possibly connected to the convent. Religious institutions often provided social services and charity to the poor of their districts.
Named after the cloister of the Terese convent. The architectural components of significant religious buildings frequently provided names for adjacent streets.
A covered passageway possibly named after a confraternity that practiced religious self-discipline or after the strict regimen followed by the Teresian Carmelites, known for their ascetic practices.
Named after the looms used in textile production, which was a major industry in this area. The textile workshops would have contained numerous looms for weaving wool and other fibers.
This canalside street may have been named after artisans who worked with laurel wood or after merchants who traded in laurel products used for medicinal and culinary purposes.

Named after small prayer chapels that may have been connected to the convent or to lay confraternities in the area. Religious devotion permeated Venetian society and small oratories were common features in neighborhoods.
A side street (ramo) possibly named after a home for 'reformed' women or former prostitutes who sought religious life. Such institutions were often linked to convents like the Terese.
Named after a school that provided education to poor children, possibly operated by the Terese convent. Religious orders frequently ran schools as part of their charitable works.
Named after the Zen family, another prominent Venetian nobili family who may have had property in this area. Noble families' residences were important landmarks in Venetian neighborhoods.
Named after a communal oven that would have served the neighborhood, possibly including the convent. Bakeries were essential facilities in urban neighborhoods, providing bread for residents.

A covered passage named after novices or young nuns at the Terese convent. 'Muneghette' is a Venetian dialect term for young nuns or novices, reflecting the important presence of the convent in local life.
